[h1]A return to form with a new approach.[/h1]
After Koei-Tecmo released Dynasty Warriors 9, it was received with most mixed reactions - due to bold, new game mechanics like all gameplay taking place in an open-world. The results felt lackluster when I tried the game, but I understood that this is a unique concept that is hard polish on the first outing. Questions rose whether KT would learn from the gameplay shortcomings and focus on their old winning formula, or take risks on incorporating the game's bold mechanics for either an improvement or a slippery slope of delusion.

4 years later after DW9: Empires came out, mainline Dynasty Warriors returns to the old formula but approaches on several new directions with Origin. While previous titles have gone bigger by the numbers and quality, Origin repacks the Dynasty Warriors to a relatively smaller scale, with a shorter but more condensed timeline. You primarily play as a fictional, silent protagonist - The Guardian of Peace - who carves his path in within China's long turmoil that marked the final period of the Han dynasty, while searching for the truth about his own past, the origin of course.

As I mentioned how condensed the timeline was presented in the game, it's worth mentioning that telling deep stories aren't something the Dynasty Warriors games have strived to pursue. Yet in Origin, the KT crew has invested more in the writing and fleshing out all the key characters involved. Some familiar characters even get overhauled in their looks and personalities, as if their exaggerated antics have been toned down to varying degrees - some have their quirks, but act more natural in their consistency. Much is brought out of them when you talk to grow the relationships. And as a long-time DW fan, I get the impression that some of them were written to be grounded and talk to me like I've been around them for a long time (as an observing fan). Also, be ready to be flattered (or weirded out) momentarily, because some characters that warm to you can give suggestive nods at most.

Between missions and interactions, I get the freedom of walking the 3D map to determine my next plan, including visiting both shops and inns in a city. The map does an excellent job depicting China's geography, helping me get better familiar with the country and the provinces dividing it.

The battle stages have got quite a facelift, with the fields looking expansive and rendering hordes of army soldiers into view from vantage points. I love the immersion, for what the game is about, and powerful attacks I get to unleash is unyieldingly satisfying. While playing as other officers is limited only through their companion roles, you get a window to be in their shoes briefly and go crazy with their powerful moves.

Dynasty Warriors: Origins marks a promising comeback through a familiar concept, with some major twists to refresh its running formula. The storytelling is quite strong by DW standards, the world building has a pretty overhaul, and the battles are kept engaging through both their tactical elements and the signature fight spectacle. 

If you're going to binge-play through Origin, be mindful that the story scenes weigh more than previous titles and it may feel like it disrupts the flow between story and action. I would recommend to play the game in max 2 hour chunks and come back later with a fresh mind. All in all, I really like the direction KT was going with this and I look forward to play the next major DLC that expands the story choices.

Dynasty Warriors: Origins in the latest entry to the long-running Dynasty Warriors series. While the series has experiences its up and downs, I am glad their experimentation has turned out to be a great success for this title.

Setting: Like the previous entries, you are going to be reliving a lot of battles that happened in late second to early third century AD of China, in which you get to live out your power fantasy of becoming a one-man-army. However, the focus of this game is not on the various historical figures of this era, but an original character. This has caused quite a discussion among the playerbase, as many liked this game for the opportunities to play as those historical figures, and relive their moments.
I personally don't mind as much, since this is not billed as a mainline entry, and I am a huge sucker for the wandering swordsman type. The idea of me mingling with those historical figures, and fighting alongside them is enough to compensate any feeling of loss of actually playing as those characters. 8/10

Gameplay: The game does not deviate much from its formula, it just introduced some new mechanics for the players. Aside from blocking enemy attacks, the player can now evade those attacks, and gain resources that lets you use skills. Skills are either locked to a certain weapon, or can be used regardless of your weapon of choice. Skills are all well-designed, with a nice blend of flair and practicality. Your character is also given a small squad of soldiers to command, and you can issue various order to them to influence the flow of the battle. Combat flows well, and consatnt changing tide of battle keeps you on your toes. I think the gameplay has a good balance of modern addition without losing its own character. 9/10

Visual: This is definitely the prettiest Dynasty Warriors game to date. Character models are visually appealing, texture works are reasonably detailed, and the special effects grabs your attenion without being overwhelming. being able to see hundres of units on the screen at once, and how you, or other powerful officers, send hundreds of them flying across the screen is a very satifying feeling. 10/10.

Overall: If you love Dynasty Warriors, this is a great buy. If you have never played, and want a starting point, this is also a great buy.

[h3]Goodness gracious, this is the greatest video game I've played in the past decade. In fact, it's one of the best I've ever played!![/h3]

Where do I even begin on this work of art?

Let's start with the story. It takes place in a tumultuous period of ancient Chinese history. Based on the Romance of the Three Kingdoms, there's so much to experience here. To know that all the events of the game are about real historical moments made it exceptionally interesting. Other than the protagonist and some other people being fictional, the story's been quite educational as it gave me a good starting point to learn more about ancient China. The story's pacing is also shockingly perfect. I was never rushed nor slowed down by the story, which is rare among games. For the story's length, it will be about 30 to 40 hours long. Completing the additional story paths will take another 20-30 hours each. All together, it's maybe an 80+ hour game.

With the characters, they all look fantastic and have personalities/traits that you normally don't find outside of Asia. The artists of the game outdid themselves with the everyone's appearances (except Xu Zhu). I wish more games had characters as pretty as Dynasty Warriors's ;(

The game's audio is phenomenal. Every battle has its own theme music to hype you up hard and even each faction has its own theme music. There is not a single dull piece of music in the entire soundtrack. Weapons sound authentic and hearing war drums beating with everyone cheering is immersive in battles. Frankly, all the sound effects are enjoyable. The Japanese voice acting is superb. The English voices sound lame and I haven't tried the Chinese ones yet.

As for the gameplay, it's utterly addictive. This is not a mindless button-mashing game. You have ten weapons with noticeably different fighting styles. Each weapon has numerous combo attacks and swappable special abilities. As you play, weapons automatically get upgraded with new moves, which can positively transform how they feel. Additionally, grinding in this game isn't necessary. However the game designers came up with a clever way to "grind", that is to do fun optional training missions to master each weapon's moves. As a bonus, all the combat animations are cinematic to watch.

The battles are surprisingly open-ended. They all take place in large, thoughtfully designed spaces and the objectives are pretty simple. So there's always multiple ways to win a battle. As the story progresses, the scale of the battles become truly [i]epic[/i]. That's a word I never use, so it means a lot. The enemies are balanced in ability, they can sometimes be tough or overwhelming but never unfair. Furthermore, you're given a small army, equipped with their own abilities, to control. You also have your own horse to ride around, it's just all too fun.

What about the small details? They've all been accounted for. You can read about all the characters you meet, replay any battle, review any cutscene, listen the soundtrack, etc. Even in cutscenes you can reread any dialogue you missed or accidentally skipped. Travelling around the map between battles is a joy. The photo mode is feature rich as well. The developers have covered pretty much anything you can think of.

Regarding performance, it's been smooth with max settings on an RTX 4070. There are some minor issues outside of battles but that's the only thing I can complain about. What I'll say is: use DLSS or FSR instead of TAA. The game is also only 50GB in size. Loading times are near instant on an SSD.

I have a very sporadic history with Dynasty Warriors, starting with the PS1 fighter, followed by the first battlefield "musou" title on the PS2, and then a LONG hiatus where I'd dabble with Xtreme Legends 8 on the Vita, and then XL 7 on PC about a decade after that. I was never a huge fan of this genre: the games always felt like good fun for about twenty minutes before the repetitiveness set in. And despite my love for Three Kingdoms lore, that wasn't enough to keep me playing.

Origins is... different from those memories. Maybe it's because I never spent serious time on any of the prior titles, or even touched any of the more recent iterations, but Origins manages to keep my attention in ways that the rest of the franchise could not. Other DW titles always felt a little floaty and loose to me, but the action in Origins feels tight, responsive, and substantial. Everything from parries to field-annihilating Musou attacks feel satisfying in all the right ways. The various weapons feel unique, with bespoke special attacks that serve meaningful purposes, a "bravery" meter that balances out the carnage, and a variety of other mechanics that make battles feel like a test of tactics and skill, rather than just a game of plowing into the thickest crowd and mashing buttons until complete (though that can definitely happen and still work). 

Surprisingly, one-on-one fights are pretty decent. While the combat obviously isn't "Rise of the Ronin" deep, Omega Force still does a good job of condensing interesting duels within a framework built for large-scale conflict. Boss fights are legitimately fun.

The game is VERY story and cutscene heavy, but fortunately the story is reliably Three Kingdoms fare. The real-time cutscenes look great, and pre-rendered cutscenes look fantastic (30 fps notwithstanding). That said, I'm a bit torn on some of the character models. Big guys like Guan Yu and Dong Zhuo look... wrong. Like, Guan Yu's head is three sizes too small for his gigantic torso, and everyone's arms/hands seem too damn short/small compared to their gigantic, rippling muscles. It seems like only the female characters have human proportions, and as expected, all the ladies look exceedingly pretty... though they still pale in comparison to the sheer bishounen powers of young Liu Bei and Cao Cao. 

The default difficulty is a bit low; anyone familiar with action games should really start on the Hero difficulty level. Also, from what I've seen so far, this game could have probably gotten away with a character creator (like Nioh 2, Wo Long, or Rise of the Ronin), because the self-insert protagonist is so incredibly blank, androgenous, and soulless (by design) that I don't think it would matter if they're male, female, attractive, or grotesque. That said, I'm still relatively early in the game, so I'd understand if something in the narrative ultimately precludes those notions. Plus, those character creators seem more up Team Ninja's alley, so I'm probably asking for too much.

Aside from that, I have very few complaints and a lot of praise yet to give as I continue with this game.

I‚Äôve grown up with this series, and Dynasty Warriors: Origins honestly broke my heart a little. It looks great, runs smoothly, but it‚Äôs lost what made Dynasty Warriors feel special.

**Bodyguards & Unit Command ‚Äì The Missing Heart of the Series**

There‚Äôs still no return of bodyguards, one of the best features from the classic games. Even with a full reboot, they didn‚Äôt try anything new. No companions, no unit command, no squad mechanics ‚Äî just your lone fighter cutting through endless crowds.

Imagine leading a small squad of archers, infantry, or cavalry that actually fought beside you. That kind of evolution would‚Äôve been perfect for this reboot. Instead, it feels like a step backward into isolation.

**Map Chaos & Busywork ‚Äì The Headless Chicken Simulator**

Almost every mission turns into a mad dash to save weak allies. You spend half your time sprinting across massive maps while objectives collapse on the other side. It‚Äôs exhausting and repetitive.

Where‚Äôs the strategy? A proper battle map or command system would‚Äôve added real depth ‚Äî give orders, call in a volley or charge, launch an ambush or fire attack, even trigger mystical weather effects inspired by Romance of the Three Kingdoms. Anything to make the chaos feel smart instead of messy.

Instead, you just chase icons. Over and over.

**Main Character ‚Äì Too Powerful for His Own Good**

The main character feels more like a demigod than a soldier. There‚Äôs no fear of dying, no thrill in surviving a tough fight. Earlier games made you feel like a warrior in the thick of a war ‚Äî fragile, desperate, pushing your limits. That tension is gone here, and with it, the excitement.

**Character Variety ‚Äì From Hundreds to One**

One of the biggest letdowns is the lack of character choice. No roster, no variety, not even a female option. For a series famous for dozens of playable officers, this is a huge downgrade. A simple character creator would‚Äôve gone a long way to fix it, but they didn‚Äôt bother.

**Lost Potential ‚Äì The Strategy That Never Returned**

What hurts most is the wasted potential. I always hoped Dynasty Warriors would blend the tactical depth of Romance of the Three Kingdoms and DW Tactics with the signature action. Instead, they‚Äôve stripped away more strategy with each new game.

I‚Äôm still hoping for a Dynasty Warriors 3 remaster to bring back that old magic, but even then, no online co-op for PC feels like another missed chance.

**Final Thoughts:**
Dynasty Warriors: Origins isn‚Äôt terrible, it‚Äôs just empty. It plays fine and looks fine, but it‚Äôs lost its heart and its soul. For veterans of the series, it feels like watching an old friend forget who they are.
